s.text: They're also genuinely curious about the phenomenon of Bush's popularity and are trying to explain it--starting from the premise that it must be justified.
They're also genuinely curious about the phenomenon of Bush's popularity and are trying to explain it--starting from the premise that it must be justified.
Reading it, you get a better sense of Bush as a character than from the tens of thousands of words lavished upon him by Texas Monthly and the Washington Post .
Here's Carlson's recounting of the way Bush mimicked Tucker's eleventh-hour appearance on Larry King Live : "Please," Bush whimpers, his lips pursed in mock desperation, "don't kill me."
They're also genuinely curious about the phenomenon of Bush's popularity and are trying to explain it--starting from the premise that it must be justified.

Carlson recounts asking Bush about his handling of the Karla Faye Tucker episode last year.
